{{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = | name = Alaa Abd El-Fatah
{{lang|ar|Ø¹ÙØ§Ø¡ Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯Ø§ÙÙØªØ§Ø­}} | honorific_suffix = | image = Alaa Abd El-Fatah profile photo.jpg | image_size = 240px | alt = | birth_name = Ø¹ÙØ§Ø¡ Ø£Ø­ÙØ¯ Ø³ÙÙ Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯ Ø§ÙÙØªØ§Ø­ | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1981|11|18}}[http://twitter.com/#!/alaa/status/83382856600129536 @EgyptianLiberal], Twitter post, "21 Jun via Choqok". The date used here as birth date is presented without explanation -- just the date -- at the post. | birth_place = [[Cairo, Egypt]] | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | body_discovered = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | residence = [[Cairo]] | nationality = [[Egypt]]ian | other_names = | ethnicity = [[Egyptians|Egyptian]] | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = | occupation = | years_active = | employer = | home_town = | criminal_charge = | criminal_penalty = | criminal_status = | religion = Muslim | spouse = Manal | partner = | parents = [[Ahmad Seif]] and [[Laila Suief]] | relatives = [[Mona Seif]] ''(sister)'' | children = Khaled | website = [http://manalaa.net/ manalaa.net] | footnotes = | box_width = }} '''Alaa Abd El Fattah''' ({{lang-ar|Ø¹ÙØ§Ø¡ Ø£Ø­ÙØ¯ Ø³ÙÙ Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯ Ø§ÙÙØªØ§Ø­}}, {{IPA-arz|ÊÃ¦ËlÃ¦ËÊ ËÃ¦Ä§mÃ¦d ËseËf ÊÃ¦bdelfatËtÃ¦ËÄ§|IPA}}; also presented in English as '''Alaa Abdel Fattah''') is an [[Egyptians|Egyptian]] [[wikt:Blogger|blogger]], software developer, and political activist. He is known for co-founding (along with his wife Manal) the Egyptian blog aggregator "''Manalaa''" and "''Omraneya"'', the first Arab blog aggregators that did not restrict inclusion based on the content of the blog.{{cite web|url=http://www.manalaa.net/ |title=Manalaa.net |publisher=Manalaa.net |accessdate=30 October 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.arabmediasociety.com/?article=692|title=Core to Commonplace: The Evolution of Egyptâs Blogosphere|publisher=Arab Media and Society|date=2008}}. In 2005 his blog won the Special Reporters Without Borders Award in Deutsche Welle's Best of Blogs competition.{{cite web|url=http://www.ifex.org/internet_censorship/2005/11/17/egyptian_couple_awarded_for_best/ |title=Egyptian Couple Awarded For Best Free Expression Blog |publisher=IFEX |accessdate=30 October 2011}} He has been active in developing Arabic-language versions of important software and platforms.[http://www.worldchanging.com/archives/001773.html Worldchanging essay] "''Arabization â It's Harder than just Right to Left''" December 2004 ==Background== El Fattah grew up in a family of activists and activism was a constant topic of discussion in his childhood. His father, Ahmed Seif El-Islam Hamad, a human rights attorney who had been arrested in 1983 by [[State Security Investigations Service]] officers, tortured and imprisoned for five years, is one of the founders of the [[Hisham Mubarak Law Center]][http://www.amnesty.org/en/news-and-updates/feature-stories/human-rights-defender-egypt-ahmed-seif-el-islam-20081209 "Human rights defender in egypt: Ahmed Seif El-Islam"] ''Amnesty International''. 9 December 2008. His mother [[Laila Soueif]], sister of [[Ahdaf Soueif]]{{cite news|author=Soueif, Ahdaf|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/2011/nov/13/egypt-stakes-have-risen |title=In Egypt, the stakes have risen |publisher=The Guardian |accessdate=2011-11-16}}, is a professor of mathematics at [[Cairo University]] and a political activist. His parents' activism dates to the days of [[Anwar Sadat]].Murphy, Kim, [http://articles.latimes.com/2011/feb/13/world/la-fg-egypt-revolutionaries-20110213 "A family nurtured in rebellion"], ''Los Angeles Times'', February 13, 2011. Retrieved 2011-11-09. During a demonstration in 2005 his mother, along with other women, were attacked by Mubarak supporters; El Fattah was said to have protected her.{{cite news|author=Bronstein, Scott|url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/meast/06/16/arab.unrest.irevolution/ |title=For Egyptian online warrior, father's torture fueled activism |publisher=CNN |accessdate=2011-06-17}} == May 2006 arrest and reaction == [[File:Alaa Abd El-Fatah using his laptop.jpg|thumb|upright|A picture of El Fattah that was used by activists demanding his release.]] On 7 May 2006, he was arrested during a peaceful protest after he called for an independent judiciary. His arrest, along with that of several other bloggers and activists, spurred solidarity protests by others around the world,{{cite web|author=McCarthy, Rory|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2006/may/08/worlddispatch.egypt |title=Cairo clamps down on dissent | World news | guardian.co.uk |work=The Guardian |location=UK |accessdate=30 October 2011}}[http://www.ethanzuckerman.com/blog/2006/05/08/egyptian-blogger-detained-for-participating-in-peaceful-protest/ blogpost], Ethan Zuckerman's blog, 05/08/2006 9:24 am. some of whom created the blog "Free Alaa"{{cite web|url=http://freealaa.blogspot.com/ |title=Freealaa blog |publisher=Freealaa.blogspot.com |date=10 May 2006 |accessdate=30 October 2011}} devoted to calling for his release from jail.{{cite web|author=Haitham Sabbah |url=http://sabbah.biz/mt/archives/2006/05/10/google-bombing-for-alaa-press-release/ |title=Google-bombing for Alaa: Press Release | Sabbah Report |publisher=Sabbah.biz |date=10 May 2006 |accessdate=30 October 2011}} El Fattah was released on 20 June 2006, after spending 45 days in jail. His wife Manal was quoted by the ''[[The Independent]]'' as saying: "There's no going back now, we'll definitely be continuing our activities."{{cite web|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/egypt-releases-blogger-jailed-for-45-days-after-insulting-president-404865.html |title=Egypt releases blogger jailed for 45 days after 'insulting' President â Middle East, World |work=The Independent |location=UK |date=21 June 2006 |accessdate=30 October 2011}} ==2011 revolution== {{Also|Human rights in Egypt under the Supreme Council of the Armed Forces}} {{Expand section|date=July 2011}} [[File:Alaa Abd El-Fatah in Tahrir Square.jpg|thumb|Alaa in [[Tahrir Square]].]] Abd El Fattah was out of Egypt on the 25th of January 2011, when the government shut down the internet in the country; he was able to collect information from family and friends by land-line phones and published to the world what was happening in Egypt during the first days of the revolution{{fact|date=November 2011}}. A few days later he was in Egypt, and was in Tahrir square in 2nd of February, participated in defending the square against the military and mobs attack, known as Egypt's Camel battle.{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/video/middleeast/2011/09/2011911174015914288.html |title=Trial begins over Egypt's 'camel battle' |work=Al Jazeera |date=11 September 2011 |accessdate=6 November 2011}} Continued his participation in the Egyptian revolution, till the fall of president Mubarak, and after that he returned to live in Egypt, when he again participated in the demonstrations against the SCAF (Supreme Council of Armed Forces) way of running the country.{{cite web|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/egypt-releases-blogger-jailed-for-45-days-after-insulting-president-404865.html |title=Egypt releases blogger jailed for 45 days after 'insulting' President â Middle East, World |work=The Independent |location=UK |date=21 June 2006 |accessdate=30 October 2011}} After voluntarily responding to a summons by a military prosecutor,{{cite web |url=http://advocacy.globalvoicesonline.org/2011/10/26/blogger-alaa-abd-el-fattah-under-threat// |title=Egyptian Blogger's Summons Adds Fuel to Campaign Against Military Trials |last=York |first=Jillian |publisher=Global Voices |date=2011-10-26}} El Fattah was jailed again on 30 October 2011, for refusing to be interrogated the charges using violence and seen & captured on security cameras holding a weapon against military forces {{cite web |url=http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/10/30/egypt-blogger-alaa-abd-el-fattah-detained-for-15-days/ |title=Egypt: Blogger Alaa Abd El Fattah Detained for 15 Days |last=Al Hussani |first=Amira |publisher=Global Voices |date=2011-10-30}} regarding 9 October 2011 protests at the [[Maspero television building|Maspero state television building]].{{cite news |url=http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/10/31/egyptians-rally-for-blogger-jailed-for-defying-military-prosecutor/ |title=Egyptians Rally for Blogger Jailed for Defying Military Prosecutor |last=Mackey |first=Robert |publisher=The New York Times |date=2011-10-31 |accessdate=2011-10-31}} Clashes during the 9 October protests resulted in the death of 28 protesters.{{cite news |url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/510199 |title=Activist gets 15 days detention in Maspero investigation |publisher=Al Masry Al Youm |last=Khazbak |first=Rana |date=2011-10-30 |accessdate=2011-10-31}} As in his 2006 imprisonment, his mother has spoken out in his support, and initiated a hunger strike in opposition to the court-martialling of civilians on November 6th.Fleishman, Jeffrey, [http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/world_now/2011/11/egypt-mother-hunger-strike-bllogger-son.html#more "Egyptian mother on hunger strike to free blogger son from prison"], ''Los Angeles Times'', November 9, 2011 7:35 am. Retrieved 2011-11-09. His father and sisters also participated in the 2011 protests.. His sister [[Mona Seif]] is a founding member of the 'No Military Trials for Civilians', a group raising awareness for the civilian detainees summoned by military prosecutors and investigating torture allegations involving military police.{{cite news |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/2011/nov/13/egypt-stakes-have-risen?newsfeed=true |title=In Egypt, the stakes have risen |last=Soueif |first=Ahdaf |publisher=The Guardian |date=13 November 2011 |accessdate=16 November 2011}} The UN Commission for Human Rightshttp://www.thedailynewsegypt.com/human-a-civil-rights/un-calls-for-release-of-egyptian-blogger.html has called for the release of Abd El Fattah and all others imprisoned for exercising free speech. == References == {{reflist}} == External links == {{Commons category|Alaa Abd El-Fatah}} *[http://manalaa.net/ manalaa.net] {{Persondata | NAME = Abdel Fatah, Alaa | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = Ø¹ÙØ§Ø¡ Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯Ø§ÙÙØªØ§Ø­ | SHORT DESCRIPTION = Egyptian human rights activist | DATE OF BIRTH = 18 November 1981 | PLACE OF BIRTH = [[Cairo, Egypt]] | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2011}} {{Egyptian Revolution of 2011}} {{Egypt-writer-stub}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Abdel Fatah, Alaa}} [[Category:1981 births]] [[Category:Egyptian bloggers]] [[Category:Egyptian human rights activists]] [[Category:Living people]] [[ar:Ø¹ÙØ§Ø¡ Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯ Ø§ÙÙØªØ§Ø­]] [[de:Abd El-Fattah]] [[it:Alaa Abd El Fatah]] [[no:Alaa Abd El-Fatah]]
